Literature Review: The coevolution of viruses and host resistance within geographic centers of plant diversity has been a long-standing topic of interest in plant pathology. The work of Francis O. Holmes, Nikolai Vavilov, and T. Harper Goodspeed laid the foundation for understanding the complex relationships between plants, pathogens, and disease resistance. This literature review aims to summarize the key findings of Holmes's work on the coevolution of tobacco mosaic virus (TMV) and host resistance, framed by the work of Vavilov on the geographic centers of origin of plants and crop wild relatives (CWRs), and Goodspeed's taxonomy of the genus Nicotiana. The review will also discuss the implications of Holmes's hypothesis on our understanding of host-pathogen coevolution and the deployment of host genes to protect crop plants from virus-associated yield losses.
